Name: METHYLCYCLOHEXANE
Description: Methylcyclohexane is a cycloalkane that is cyclohexane substituted by a single methyl group. It has a role as an aprotic solvent, a plant metabolite and a human metabolite. It is a cycloalkane and a volatile organic compound. It derives from a hydride of a cyclohexane.

environmental_biodegradations.References: Verschueren, K. Handbook of Environmental Data of Organic Chemicals. 2nd ed. New York, NY: Van Nostrand Reinhold Co., 1983., p. 842
environmental_biodegradations.Value: Biodegradation: 75% after 192 hr at 13 °C (initial concentration: 0.05 ug/l)

logP.References: Hansch, C., Leo, A., D. Hoekman. Exploring QSAR - Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. Washington, DC: American Chemical Society., 1995., p. 35

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists. Documentation of the Threshold Limit Values and Biological Exposure Indices. 5th ed. Cincinnati, OH: American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists, 1986., p. 384
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: INHALATION ... OF 7500 TO 10,000 PPM FOR TWO HOURS CAUSED PROSTRATION IN WHITE MICE, AND 10,000 TO 12,500 PPM WAS FATAL. ... ACUTE TOXICITY OF METHYLCYCLOHEXANE WAS GREATER THAN THAT OF HEPTANE, BUT LESS THAN THAT OF OCTANE. ... 1200 PPM /WAS REPORTED/ TO BE INNOCUOUS FOR RABBITS. PROLONGED EXPOSURE AT 370 PPM APPEARED TO BE HARMLESS TO MONKEYS.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists. Documentation of the Threshold Limit Values for Substances in Workroom Air. Third Edition, 1971. Cincinnati, Ohio: American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists, 1971. (Plus supplements to 1979), p. 162
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: NO EFFECTS RESULTED FROM REPEATED EXPOSURES OF RABBITS AT 1160 PPM FOR 10 WEEKS, AND ONLY SLIGHT KIDNEY AND LIVER INJURY WAS OBSERVED AT 3330 PPM.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Gosselin, R.E., R.P. Smith, H.C. Hodge. Clinical Toxicology of Commercial Products. 5th ed. Baltimore: Williams and Wilkins, 1984., p. II-151
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: ORAL DOSE IN RABBITS CAUSED MILD LETHARGY, SEVERE DIARRHEA AND CIRCULATORY COLLAPSE. VASCULAR & DEGENERATIVE LESIONS ARE SEEN IN KIDNEY & LIVER.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Patty, F. (ed.). Industrial Hygiene and Toxicology: Volume II: Toxicology. 2nd ed. New York: Interscience Publishers, 1963., p. 1212
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: RABBITS EXPOSED TO 15,000 PPM ... DIED IN 70 MIN. EFFECTS OBSERVED PRECEDING DEATH WERE: CONJUNCTIVAL CONGESTION, SALIVATION, LABORED BREATHING ... ./SRP: CNS DEPRESSION/ CONVULSIONS.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Patty, F. (ed.). Industrial Hygiene and Toxicology: Volume II: Toxicology. 2nd ed. New York: Interscience Publishers, 1963., p. 1212
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: ALL RABBITS DIED FOLLOWING EXPOSURE TO 10,000 PPM ... 6 HR/DAY, 5 DAYS/WK FOR 2 WK; ONE-FOURTH ... EXPOSED TO 7300 PPM (0.73%) FOR SIMILAR TIME DIED. FOUR WK EXPOSURE OF RABBITS TO 5600 PPM (0.56%) CAUSED ... SLIGHT LETHARGY WHICH WAS NOTOBSERVED AT 1/2 THIS CONCN.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: KLEIN SA ET AL; AEROSP MED RES LAB, (TECH REP) AMRL-TR (US) (AMRL-TR-125): 429-55 (1975)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: AQUEOUS CONCN OF METHYLCYCLOHEXANE WHICH WAS NONLETHAL TO RAINBOW TROUT (SALMO GAIRDNERI) WAS LESS THAN 0.8 MG/L. SEVEN DAY EXPOSURE TO CONCN OF 0.83-1.85 MG/L CAUSED LETHALITY IN FLAGFISH.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Snyder, R. (ed.) Ethel Browning's Toxicity and Metabolism of Industrial Solvents. 2nd ed. Volume 1: Hydrocarbons. Amsterdam - New York - Oxford: Elsevier, 1987., p. 239
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: Inhalation of 30-40 mg/l methylcyclohexane produced ... /CNS depression/ in mice; 40-50 mg/l (10,000-12,500 ppm) was the minimum lethal dose.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Snyder, R. (ed.) Ethel Browning's Toxicity and Metabolism of Industrial Solvents. 2nd ed. Volume 1: Hydrocarbons. Amsterdam - New York - Oxford: Elsevier, 1987., p. 239
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: Aspiration of 0.2 ml methylcyclohexane into the lungs killed 3 out of 3 male Wistar albino rats (200-300 g) within 24 hr; lung weights of treated rats were almost 2 fold greater than controls.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Snyder, R. (ed.) Ethel Browning's Toxicity and Metabolism of Industrial Solvents. 2nd ed. Volume 1: Hydrocarbons. Amsterdam - New York - Oxford: Elsevier, 1987., p. 239
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: Severe convulsions and rapid ... /CNS depression/ occurred in rabbits during a 70 min exposure to 59.9 mg/l (15,227 ppm).

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Snyder, R. (ed.) Ethel Browning's Toxicity and Metabolism of Industrial Solvents. 2nd ed. Volume 1: Hydrocarbons. Amsterdam - New York - Oxford: Elsevier, 1987., p. 240
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: The minimal lethal oral dose of methylcyclohexane in rabbits was 4.0-4.5 g/kg. Severe diarrhea occurred; however, no convulsions or demonstrable abmormalities in the cellular elements of the blood were observed in the surviving rabbits. There was a 7 fold increase in the amount of glucuronide excreted in the urine from the treated animals, which was estimated to represent 4-5% of the dose.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Snyder, R. (ed.) Ethel Browning's Toxicity and Metabolism of Industrial Solvents. 2nd ed. Volume 1: Hydrocarbons. Amsterdam - New York - Oxford: Elsevier, 1987., p. 240
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: Inhalation exposure to 4.57 mg/l (1162 ppm at 760 mm Hg, 25 °C) methylcyclohexane for 10 wk (6 hr/day, 5 day/wk) appeared to be innocuous to rabbits. Exposure to 11.35 mg/l (2886 ppm) for 90 hr (6 hr/day, 5 day/wk) produced barely discernable microscopic evidence of cellular injury in the liver and kidneys. Death occurred among rabbits exposed repeatedly to 28.75 mg/l (7308 ppm) or higher for 60 hr (6 hr/day, 5 day/wk); death was preceeded by conjunctival congestion with mucoid secretion and lacrimation, salivation, coughing, sneezing, labored breathing, and diarrhea.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Snyder, R. (ed.) Ethel Browning's Toxicity and Metabolism of Industrial Solvents. 2nd ed. Volume 1: Hydrocarbons. Amsterdam - New York - Oxford: Elsevier, 1987., p. 240
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: Severe convulsions and light ... /CNS depression/ occurred during a 2 wk exposure (6 hr/day, 5 day/wk) of rabbits to 39.55 mg/l (9848 ppm); all rabbits had died by the end of the 2 wk exposure.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Snyder, R. (ed.) Ethel Browning's Toxicity and Metabolism of Industrial Solvents. 2nd ed. Volume 1: Hydrocarbons. Amsterdam - New York - Oxford: Elsevier, 1987., p. 240
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: No illness or microscopic evidence of injurious effects to any tissues were observed in monkeys exposed to 1.46 mg/l (372 ppm at 760 mm Hg, 25 °C) methylcyclohexane for fifty 6 hr periods.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Snyder, R. (ed.) Ethel Browning's Toxicity and Metabolism of Industrial Solvents. 2nd ed. Volume 1: Hydrocarbons. Amsterdam - New York - Oxford: Elsevier, 1987., p. 240
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: Dermal application of twelve 5 ml aliquots of methylcyclohexane applied at 5 min intervals per day on 6 consecutive days induced local irritation and thickening, but did not cause death in rabbits.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Kinkead ER et al; Aerosp Med Res Lab, Tech Rep AMRL-TR (US) (AMRL-TR-79-68 Proc Conf Environ Toxicol): 154-60 (1979)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: Exposure of rats and mice to 6564 ppm methylcyclohexane caused immediate hyperactivity, whereas 4200 ppm appeared to be a safe 1-hr exposure limit. One-hour exposure of dogs to 4071 ppm caused no behavioral or histopathological effects.
